dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN in his 70s walks along a narrow stretch of grass separating a busy road from a railroad yard. The man walks purposefully, despite the hesitant gait and clouded eyes of a longtime alcoholic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now a bit dazed and slowed by fatigue, the man walks past sign reading BILLINGS CITY LIMITS. A state patrol cruiser pulls up in front of him, and a TROOPER gets out. EXT. DAVID’S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY 3 A modest structure set against a bluff. INT. DAVID’S APARTMENT - DAY 4 DAVID GRANT - 40 - sits in a recliner in a sparsely-furni living room. He watches TV and drinks from a plastic bott of Mountain Dew. The doorbell rings. He gets up and opens the door. It’s his recent ex-girlfri NOEL with two suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: NOEL
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wow. Are you moving back in?

dialogues.speaker: NOEL
dialogues.text: No, these are yours. I’m just returning them.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Right. Thanks. Do you want to come in? She thinks a moment before stepping inside and maintains polite distance. She notices a droopy plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, you’re supposed to water that plant. It’s a plant. David goes to the kitchen to fill a container with water.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’d like you to change your mind.

dialogues.speaker: NOEL
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You know what it means. I want you to move back in.

dialogues.speaker: NOEL
dialogues.text: I just moved out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So two years, and we’re back to dating.

dialogues.speaker: NOEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know yet. We’ll see ina while.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Are we still having sex?

dialogues.speaker: NOEL
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think we are.

dialogues.speaker: NOEL
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Usually I fall asleep. Not in the mood for a joke --

dialogues.speaker: NOEL
dialogues.text: I’ve got to go.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Are you saying we can’t be together again unless we get married?  Blue (10-12-2012) 3.

dialogues.speaker: NOEL
dialogues.text: Get married, break up, I don’t know. Let’s do both. Let’s just do something. The phone rings. David and Noél wait in silence as the machine eventually picks up.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Pick up or call me back right now. It’s your father -- he’s gone crazy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. He runs to pick up the phone. Noél starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi, Mom. I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: David, it’s your mother.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s why I said, “Hi, Mom.”

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I’m going to do with him. I’m going to put him in a goddamned nursing home is what I’m going to do. I’m too old for this. As Kate continues, David waves a weak goodbye to Noél.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOODY GRANT sits on a folding chair in a cinder-block off A SHERIFF leads David inside.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There’s the man of the hour.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The man of the hour.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.  Blue (10-12-2012) 4. In addition to general confusion, Woody is deaf in one ea

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So you told the sheriff you were walking to... Nebraska?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: That’s right. To get my million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What million dollars?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I won a million dollars. He pulls a crinkled letter from his jacket pocket, which unfolds and labors to read. WOODY (CONT’D) “We are now authorized to pay one million dollars to Mr. Woodrow T. Grant of Billings, Montana.”

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let me see. Woody hands David the letter.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Your mother won’t take me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (reading) Mega Sweepstakes Marketing. Dad, this is a total come-on. It’s one of the oldest gimmicks in the book. I didn’t even know they did this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: They can’t say it if it’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They’re just trying to sell you magazine subscriptions.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: It says I won.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So let’s mail it in. I’11 help you.  Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t trust the mail with a million dollars. EXT. WOODY AND KATE’S HOUSE - DAY A modest home. Woody and David get out of David’s car. David pulls a ver full laundry basket from his back seat. They go inside the kitchen door. INT. WOODY AND KATE’S KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS KATE GRANT awaits them wearing a faded floral housecoat. 7 The house has a tired, 70s-era décor. David puts his basket i the laundry room at one end of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You dumb cluck. You pretty near gave me a heart attack!

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Now just cool your jets.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: This is the second time he’s tried to sneak out. I never knew the son- of-a-bitch even wanted to be a millionaire. He should have thought about that years ago and worked for it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What would you do with a million dollars anyway, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Buy a new truck.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You can’t drive.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I‘1l get my license back.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Tell me when you do so I can stay off the road.  Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I need an air compressor too.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Are you still harping on that?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Ed Pegram still has mine.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That’s because he’s a thief.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: He’s not a thief. I lent it to him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Who's Ed Pegram?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Guy I knew back in Hawthorne.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: When did he borrow it?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Seventy-four.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s almost forty years. He lives two states away. I’d say he stole it.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: That’s why I need a new one. Woody heads down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Where you off to now?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Lyin’ down.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: He even sleeps with that stupid letter. He’s memorized it word for word. I didn’t think he could memorize anything anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (opening the refrigerator) Hey, what’s with this casserole?  Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It’s lasagna. It’s still good. Take it. And take some bananas. I bought a whole lot of them yesterday. Your father makes me so nervous. You know what I’d do with a million dollars -- I’d put him in a home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David works with a YOUNG COUPLE inside a soundproof DEMO ROOM. David and the man headbang to a rock anthem. The woman looks bored. Soon David leads them back into the showroom.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Like I say, you basically just test- drove a Cadillac or Rolls Royce or whatever. Wasn’t that awesome?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Totally.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But that’s not to say I can’t set you up with a whole lot more reasonable speakers that’1l still blow your mind if you’re worried the Wilsons are going to set you back too much. The way they design speakers anymore, you can’t make a mistake. The woman tugs on her boyfriend’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Great. I think, uh, I think we just need to discuss this and get back to you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Here’s my card. Give me a call anytime if you have any more questions.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Excellent, Mark, Janice. Pleasure.  10 Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Juh-neece.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Juh-neece. Sorry. David watches them go. They won’t be back.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: David, your mother’s on line one. EXT. WOODY AND KATE’S HOUSE - DAY David gets out of his car and finds his mother near the garage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Where’d they find him this time?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Way the hell out on King Avenue by the Albertson’s. I can’t take it anymore. Ross is in there trying to talk some sense into him. David goes into the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- where David’s brother ROSS watches Woody work on the engine of a very old Ford pickup. Ross has a sportcoat, and perfect haircut.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Hi, Dave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Ross. What’s going on, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Talk to Ma and Ross. They seem to know it all.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m asking you.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Can't get her to turn over.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s because it’s been sitting there for ten years. 10 tie,  Blue (10-12-2012) 9.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I‘1l get her runnin’.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: He still thinks he’s going to Lincoln to get his money.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Gotta get there by the 5th.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Hey Dad, how come you didn’t think of fixing the truck first or take a bus? Why’d you just start walking? Woody looks up a moment, thinks about that, then gets bac work. David leads his brother out of the garage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Don’t pull his chain like that. The poor guy doesn’t know what’s going on half the time.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I cut the solenoid wire and stuck it back in. That’1l slow him down. And Mom’s right -- it’s time to think about a home. She can’t handle him anymore. It’s not fair to her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He doesn’t need a nursing home. He just...the guy just needs something to live for. That’s all this is about.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Yeah, and it’s pathetic. Seems like drinking always gave him more than enough to live for until now.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Go easy on the man, okay? He'll probably forget all about this ina day or two.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: And then it’1l be some other demented crap, like the infomercial stuff last year. Mom and I are looking at reality, and you'd better start too. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A home would be in his best interest -- which, let’s face it -- is more than he ever thought about with us. He never gave a shit about you or me. They peek inside the garage. Woody remains focused.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I saw you anchoring the other night. Nice job.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: First time in the chair, right?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Kelly Ann Castillo called in sick, so I got to fill in, yeah. And apparently I didn’t stink up the place too much, so...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Tom Brokaw. The new Tom Brokaw of Billings.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: I don’t know about Tom Brokaw exactly, but you know, yeah, it’s looking pretty good. I’ve paid my dues. Plus, looks like Kelly Ann's got some kind of bad infection. Then from inside the garage --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You put that heap of shit on the road, I swear to God I’1l call the police! INT. DAVID’S APARTMENT - DAY 11 David sits in his recliner drinking beer and watching a documentary about Tiger Woods.

dialogues.speaker: TV NARRATOR
dialogues.text: When Earl Woods died, friends say a piece of Tiger died with him.  12 Blue (10-12-2012) 11.

dialogues.speaker: TIGER WOODS, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: My dad has always taught me these words: care and share... David notices the time and switches the channel.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Billings Chamber of Commerce director Dee Pomerantz says a new convention center could bring in upwards of five million dollars to the Magic City. But opponents, led by Councilman Reilly Tilden, claim the plan is a “Pie in the Big Sky idea" that will cost taxpayers more than it's worth. The Council is expected to debate the proposal in Monday's session. Coming up next, is it time to pull out that old umbrella? Debbie Ontiveros has your soggy work week forecast. Then in Sports, Carter brings us the story of a Hardin snowmobiler who may have lost his legs, but not his will to compete. That and more coming up after the break. Stay with us.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Ross. The phone rings. David looks at the caller ID, drops his head and answers with dread.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: David, it’s your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody walks down the sidewalk toward the BUS STATION. Dav pulls up alongside him in his car and rolls down the wind

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad. Dad!

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Leave me alone. David guns the car ahead of Woody, stops and gets out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Come on. Let me take you home.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’m going to Lincoln if it’s the last thing I do. I don’t care what you people think.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Listen to me. You didn’t win anything. It’s a complete scam. So you’ve got to stop this, okay? Woody looks at David as though maybe his son is finally making sense. Then he starts walking again.  13 Blue (10-12-2012) 12.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’m running out of time.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You don’t even have a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’m not stayin’ there.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can’t let you go.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: It’s none of your business.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. I’m your son.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Then why don’t you take me?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can’t just drop everything and drive to Lincoln, Nebraska.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: What else you got goin’ on? David blinks as he absorbs this. Even a broken clock is right twice a day. INT. WOODY AND KATE’S DRIVEWAY - DAY 13 As David puts an old suitcase of his father’s into the tr of his car, Kate lays into him.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing? There’s no money!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I realize that. Woody sits in the passenger seat, seemingly oblivious to discussion.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Have you lost your marbles too? Get your father out of your car this goddamned instant. You need to help me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m the one who does all the work around here. Your father just sits there. Look at him. He’s useless. His mother spoiled him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We'll just be gone a couple of days. Don’t worry. We'll be back before you know it. Why don’t you just enjoy the time alone? You always complain about having him around.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What about your job? David gets in the car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I told them I was sick.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Sick in the head. I’m going to tell Ross to call you. He’1l back me up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sounds great. Bye, Mom. David drives away.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You’re just like your father, stubborn as a mule! Couple of lunatics!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David’s Subaru heads southeast toward Wyoming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Woody drive in silence for a while before --

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: When you get tired, you let me know, and I’1l drive.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You can’t drive.  16 17 14.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because your license was suspended for drinking.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t drink.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Just a beer now and then.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s true. One continuous fifty- year beer.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: (pointing) I can sure as hell drive better than that moron.
-- The car continues on Interstate 90 amid the wide-open spaces of Montana.

dialogues.speaker: -- WELCOME TO WYOMING
dialogues.text: -- A freight train travels alongside the highway. Woody stares at it like a little kid. David casts glances at hi father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While filling up the car, David stares into space taking mental stock of his strange situation. Once he replaces t nozzle, he turns to find his father. David’s eyes follow the direction of the passenger door l open, and he spots a SALOON.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David finds Woody seated comfortably amid a gaggle of weathered afternoon DRINKERS.  18 19 Blue (10-12-2012) 15.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Dad, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I was thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Good to see you’re not drinking.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Beer ain’t drinking. (downing the rest of his Coors) Let’s go.
-- The car passes through shifting landscapes and impress big cloudy skies.

dialogues.speaker: -- WELCOME TO SOUTH DAKOTA
dialogues.text: -- A crew of BIKERS swarms and passes the car. -- The car passes billboards, one advertising MOUNT RUSHM INT. DAVID’S CAR - DAY 19 David smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How about we go see Mount Rushmore?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: We don’t have time for that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s just a half hour off the interstate. We’re right here.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: It’s just a bunch of rocks.  Blue (10-12-2012) 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Woody have stopped their car at a PULL-OFF offe a good if slightly distant view of the presidents.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So what do you think, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Doesn’t look finished to me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Looks like somebody got bored doin’ it. Washington’s the only one with any clothes, and they’re just sort of roughed in. Lincoln doesn’t even have an ear. David takes a look -- his dad’s got a point. Woody turns away. WOODY (CONT’D) Okay, now we seen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. The door cracks open, and someone sneaks in before banging into a table and crashing to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad? David turns on the light, jumps out of bed, and finds Woo face down and motionless.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. He rolls Woody over and sees that he’s bleeding from a na gash above the eye. David runs to the bathroom and return with a towel.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’m all right.  Blue (10-12-2012) 16A. David presses the towel onto Woody’s forehead.  Blue (10-12-2012) 17.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You’ve been drinking.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t. I’m fine. Go back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David watches a DOCTOR finish dressing Woody’s wound.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: All righty, that ought to do it. Give me a sec. The doctor walks out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who you got in there?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just an old drunk who cut his head.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Where’s my teeth?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You lost your teeth? Woody answers with a grin -- he is missing four upper fro teeth.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you leave them at the motel?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The tavern?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t in no tavern.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did you leave them at the place where they serve alcohol that you don’t call a tavern?  24 Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Must have been when I fell by the tracks. The doctor returns, speaks to David.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Considering it’s a pretty bad head wound, his age, and history of drinking, I think we should keep him in the hospital a day or so for observation.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t drink.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You hear that, Dad? We won’t be making Lincoln by Friday.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: We got till Monday.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We're going to take you back home.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’m not going home.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can’t wait until Monday. That means I wouldn’t be back at work till Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Sellin’ record players. (to doctor) I won a million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Congratulations. That’ll just about cover one day in the hospital. David offers a weak courtesy laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody lies in bed like a corpse -- eyes closed, mouth The TV is on. David enters, shakes his father awake. 18. 24 slack.  Blue (10-12-2012) 18a.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I looked, but I couldn’t find your teeth anywhere.  25 Blue (10-12-2012) 19.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: They’re by the tracks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You have to be more specific than railroad tracks that run from the Atlantic to the Pacific. Listen, Mom talked to Uncle Ray and Aunt Martha. They’re going to put us up in Hawthorne over the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go to Hawthorne. Why can’t we just go direct to Lincoln?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because there’s no sense going to Lincoln over the weekend. I’11 get you there Monday morning. Anyway, Aunt Martha said she’d invite all your brothers over and have a little get-together on Sunday. Mom’s coming down on the bus, maybe Ross and Marcie too. It’ll be nice.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go to Hawthorne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Woody search the ground along tracks separating tavern from a small commercial area, including a motel.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do you remember where you fell?  Blue (10-12-2012) 20. They keep looking. David brightens and picks something up

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, Dad, I found it. Here it is. (running over) Oh, wait. This isn’t yours. Woody nods and keeps looking.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was kidding. Here. Woody takes the teeth and brushes off them off.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: This ain’t mine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I was putting you on. It’s yours.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: No, it’s not.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Whose else is it going to be? See if it fits.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: These ain’t my teeth.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They have to be.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I should know my own teeth. David looks at his father in disbelief and starts looking again. WOODY (CONT’D) Of course they’re my teeth. Don’t be a moron.  26 27

dialogues.speaker: A28
dialogues.text: 28 Blue (10-12-2012) 21. Woody inserts his teeth and grins. WOODY (CONT’D) Come on. Let’s go.

-- David's car passes a massive windmill farm. -- David and Woody pass a faded, pocked sign reading “Nebraska, The Good Life. Home of Arbor Day.” -- Other TBD. INT./EXT. DAVID’S CAR - DAY 27 A farm report is on the radio as David and Woody reach a RURAL CROSSROADS.

dialogues.speaker: FARM REPORT, (ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: Barrows and gilts are 94 higher, averaging 74.99...

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Say, turn up here.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, we should stay on 20.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I want to show you something. Woody directs David to turn onto a gravel COUNTRY ROAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David’s Subaru turns now from the gravel road back onto a PAVED COUNTRY ROAD.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR --
dialogues.text: David is curious as Woody directs him down a desolate roa

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: There it is. Pull in there.  Blue (10-12-2012) 21a.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David pulls into the driveway. They get out.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: They used to have a big sign with a great big cowboy on it. Must have been thirty foot tall.  30 31 32 22. David looks at the motel. Trees grow out of the windows. WOODY (CONT’D) When I was a boy, my brothers and I always wanted to come by and see the big cowboy. Real big cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is that him? David points to a rusted sign for the RUSTLER ROOST lying amid tall weeds. The big cowboy with the buckshot-pummele face is no more than ten feet tall.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Seemed bigger then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David’s car drives slowly into the business district, a w street with head-in parking spots filled mainly with pick trucks. The buildings -- many boarded up -- pre-date 1960 with some clearly over a century old. INT. DAVID’S CAR - CONTINUOUS 31 Woody twists around to take it all in. EXT. RAY AND MARTHA’S HOUSE - DAY 32 David stops at an old two-story house with junk cars out front. AUNT MARTHA, a lively 70, comes out to greet them.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Well, hello there, boys.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi, Aunt Martha. She hugs them both.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Martha.  33 Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Look at you, Davey. You couldn’t have been more than 15 last time we saw you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s what I was saying to Dad. Long time.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Well, what have you got to say for yourself, Woody?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Nothin’.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: What’d you do to your head?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Fell.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: You Grant brothers sure are men of few words. INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S TV ROOM - DAY 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Martha leads Woody and David through the house. Seat in front of the TV are Woody’s older brother RAY and Davi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: twin layabout cousins BART and COLE, too old to be living home.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Look who I found hanging around out front, Ray. Your little brother Woody.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: I can see that. What’s up, Woody?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Nothing. How about you?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: Not much.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi, Uncle Ray. Ray nods as if not entirely sure he knows who David is. stare at each other a few seconds in silence. All  Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: You boys remember your cousin David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Hey, Bart. Cole.

dialogues.speaker: BART AND COLE
dialogues.text: Hi. Hey.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Man, it’s been a long time since we all met as kids. What’re you guys up to?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Not much.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: This economy has just tore up Hawthorne, Davey. Things are hard for young men.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m in the home theater and electronics business myself. Rough time, I’1l tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: Cole here did some jail.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Don’t bring that up.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Bitch lied through her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: I will not allow that kind of language in my house.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: (to Woody and David) Now, boys, you sit down. You must be starving. I made sandwiches. Woody and David sit as Martha heads to the kitchen. 24.  Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: So how long’d it take you to get here?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t know. We got sort of waylaid in Rapid City. That's where Dad had his little accident.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: But how long total?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, couple of days, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: From Billings? How far’s that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Probably about 750 miles.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: It took you two days to drive 750 miles? What are you driving, a dump truck or something?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s a Subaru. Outback.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Hell, I drove up from Dallas one time. That’s 850 miles. I done that in eight hours.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s over 100 miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Bart was movin’.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Here you go, boys. Dig in.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Shit, two days from Montana. Sombitch must have been drivin’ in reverse.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Boys, language! 25.  34 Blue (10-12-2012) INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S DINING ROOM - DAY The reunited family sit silently in the parlor. Then --

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Ray’s foot’s been’s bothering him, ain’t that right?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. It just hurts. David notices that Woody’s been staring off into space.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did you get that, Dad? Dad?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Uncle Ray’s foot hurts.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Ray) Everything else good, though?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: Not really. David takes a sip of the off-brand soda in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Kate says they got Ross on the news out there. Says he’s doing real good.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yep. Yeah, he’s doing great.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Good for him. He was always quite a go-getter, wasn’t he?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Two goddamn days from Billings! Bart and Cole laugh. 26. 34  35 36 Blue (10-12-2012) 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Woody walks David along the storefronts of his early l he betrays not a shred of nostalgia.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Rottle’s Clothing used to be here. (an antiques store) That was the bank.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Must’ve changed a lot since your day. Woody doesn’t answer. They continue to walk in silence as David tries to imagine Woody’s impressions. Eventually Woody leads David across the street to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody pokes his head into the service bay, where two MEXI MECHANICS work on a car.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I used to own this garage.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Own it? I thought the air compressor guy did.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Ed Pegram.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, I thought he owned it.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: We were partners.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Huh. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I sold it to him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: For how much?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Eight hundred.  Blue (10-12-2012) 28.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You sold him half of a business for eight hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: That was a lot of money back then.

dialogues.speaker: BIG MECHANIC
dialogues.text: You need something?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My dad here used to own this place.

dialogues.speaker: BIG MECHANIC
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Woody and David enter. Woody steps to the car they’re working on and peers under the hood.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: So what you fellas have going on here?

dialogues.speaker: SMALL MECHANIC
dialogues.text: Oh, we just replacing the transmission cooler lines.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Do you know Ed Pegram?

dialogues.speaker: BIG MECHANIC
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Ed Pegram. Used to own this place too. They look at each other and shake their heads. WOODY (CONT’D) (to Small Mechanic) Glasses! You’re using the wrong wrench.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Come on, Dad. Let’s get going. (to the mechanics) Good talking to you. The mechanics stare after David and Woody as they walk aw

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: That moron was using the wrong wrench.  37 38 Blue (10-12-2012) 29,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue their stroll until happening upon the SODBU BAR. Woody stops.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Let’s see if there’s anyone I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, Woody makes a perfunctory scan for familiar faces but it’s practically empty. *

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Pretty quiet in here. David starts toward the door, but with automatic reflex W takes a seat at the bar. David reluctantly follows -- wha the hell? A perky, earthy FEMALE BARTENDER comes over.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Hi, boys. What can I get you today?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Beer.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: What kind of beer you want?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Anything’s fine. Coors if you got it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’1l have a Mountain Dew.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Fresh out of Coors. Don’t come in * till Monday. *

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Bud then. *

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Bud and a Dew. *

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Tom Varnik still own this place?  Blue (10-12-2012) 29a.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Never heard of him. Must be before my time.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: (to David) I used to know everybody in here.  Blue (10-12-2012) 30.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is this where you had your first drink?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: No, Dad used to let me sip his beer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So I guess you kept up that fine family tradition with Ross and me.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: You liked it, as I recall.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I was like six.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: A sip of beer isn’t going to kill you when you’re only six. I thought you drank. Come on, have a beer with your old man.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’ve been trying to give it up.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I was starting to... It just wasn’t helping.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I suppose now you're okay. The bartender sets the drinks down.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Say, could I have a beer too?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You betcha.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Going to drink with my dad.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Empty bottles on the table, dimmer light from outside, an more PATRONS in the bar suggest time has passed.  Blue (10-12-2012) 31. Woody is about the same, but David is a little drunk. He finishes a beer and has another on deck.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did you and Mom used to come here?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I didn’t tell you that Noél and I broke up.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Noél -- you know, the girl I've been living with for the past two years. She moved out. We broke up.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: (no idea) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Maybe I should have asked her to get married, I don’t know. I just... I just never felt sure, you know what I mean? How are you supposed to know when you’re sure? Were you sure?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How did you and Mom end up getting married?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: She wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You didn’t?  Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I figured what the hell.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Were you ever sorry you married her?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: All the time. David sips his beer, eager to take this in. WOODY (CONT’D) It could have been worse.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You must have been in love. At least at first.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Never came up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did you ever talk about having kids -- how many you wanted, stuff like that?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Then why did you have us?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I wanted to screw, and your mother’s Catholic, so you figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So you and Mom never actually talked about whether you wanted kids or not?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I figured if we kept on screwin’, we'd end up with a couple of you. David tries to keep from flinching.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did you ever think about leaving her? 32.  Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’d just end up with somebody else who give me shit all the time.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’d say she’s put up with your drinking all these years.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t drink that much.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You’re an alcoholic.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean, bullshit? I knew you had a problem when I was eight. I used to watch you hide your booze in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: You stole it. I figured it was you. You cost me a lot of money

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, I poured it out. I was sick of seeing you drunk all the time.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: You'd never catch your brother sneaking around like that. I served my country, I pay my taxes. It’s my right to do whatever the goddamn hell I want.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So I guess you do drink.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: A lot.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: All right, so I like to drink, goddammit! So what? You do what you want, and so do I. You’d drink too if you were married to your mother. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WOODY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It ain’t your job to tell me what to do, you little cocksucker! Woody gets up and leaves the bar. David blinks a few time at the outburst, slaps money on the table and runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David catches up to Woody, striding down the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: What? Neither knows what to say for a moment, and they look awa from each other.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Shall I take you back to Ray and Martha's?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. They look down the street, where the only light is the flashing sign for the BLINKER TAVERN. Woody starts toward the blinking light. David follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter this bar, much more active than the Sodbuster. Woody spots none other than ED PEGRAM sitting with a coup of BUDDIES and heads over.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Say, don’t you owe me a couple of bucks? It takes Ed a couple of seconds to believe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Christ almighty, it’s Woody Grant! How the hell are you? Didn’t think I’d ever see you back in Hawthorne. Fellas, this is my old buddy Woody. Slide over, will you? Let’s make room.  4l 42 Blue (10-12-2012) 35. Ed’s about 65 and is big and rough-looking. Woody takes a seat, leaving David standing awkwardly. ED PEGRAM (CONT’D) Jesus Christ, Woody. How the hell you been?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too. Can’t complain. Boy, long time, Woody. Long time.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m David. Woody’s son. How are you, Ed?

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Davey? No shit. Last time I seen you, you was just a little shaver. How you doing there, guy? I used to give you candy bars at the garage when you was only about this high.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you. And apparently my Dad used to give you air compressors.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nothing. Dad, I’m going to the bathroom. (leaning over to whisper) For God's sake, don’t say anything about the money. Woody nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As David goes about his business, he hears cheering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David emerges from the bathroom to a boisterous tavern.  43

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Goddamn, Woody Grant’s a millionaire! Who would’ve thought it? This round’s on Woody! Hee ha! Woody beams. David stares in disbelief. EXT. RAY AND MARTHA’S HOUSE - NIGHT 43 David’s Suzuki arrives outside and parks. Woody is apparently so drunk that David has to go around pull him out of the passenger side before guiding him by shoulders into the house.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Come on, Dad. That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Did you see the look on their faces?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes, I saw.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I said, did you see the look on those fellas’ faces? They go inside and close the door behind them. INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S SPARE BEDROOM - NIGHT A44 David lies awake on the trundle bed while Woody snores aw on the bed above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Hawthorne and its environs awakening to a new day -- images of rural beauty and small-town decay. INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S KITCHEN - DAY 45 Hungover, David and Woody enter to find Ray, Bart and Col seated at the table while Aunt Martha cooks breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Morning, boys. Slept in a little late, didn’t you?  Blue (10-12-2012) 36A.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Morning. As they sit --  Blue (10-12-2012) 37.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it’d be great if you have some coffee. He stops short as he notices that his uncle and cousins a staring at Woody and him with goofy grins.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: Got a call from Lowell Meyerson this morning.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: And Mary Jurak. Woody here’s the talk of the town.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell us you was rich, Woody?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: David said not to.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He’s not rich.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: You could have told us the real reason you were coming through town.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: We're just tickled for you.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: You got it on you?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'd like to see what a million bucks looks like.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s not, see, it’s not like that really.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What’s it like then, really?  Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: We have to go to Lincoln to get it.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Goddamn, you won the Powerball?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Show us the ticket. Woody starts to reach into his pocket, but David stops

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Honestly, he didn’t win anything.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I didn’t win anything.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: I don’t blame you, Woody. I wouldn’t broadcast it either, not till I had it in the bank. Don’t want to attract buzzards neither.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Hey, Bart and me’1ll drive you.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Sure, we could get you to Lincoln in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Lincoln’s over 200 miles.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Okay, hour and a half. What would it take you?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: Must be nice winning that kind of scratch. We’re real proud of you. And I know Ma and Pa would’ve been real proud too.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Shit yeah, must be nice. David looks at his withered, unshaven father.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is it nice, Dad? 38. him.  46 Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Is what nice?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Winning all that money. Woody takes in all the faces looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s pretty nice.
-- Hawthorne’s lone stoplight blinks and blinks. -- Wind rustles through the weeping willow trees at the Hawthorne cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s not much of a depot -- just a bench outside a post office. David sits waiting with Woody. BERNIE BOWEN ambles up.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE BOWEN
dialogues.text: Hey there, Woody. Remember me? Woody doesn’t look too sure.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE BOWEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bernie Bowen. How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE BOWEN
dialogues.text: That’s what I hear! Everybody's sayin’ how Woody Grant’s a millionaire. Why, that’s the most exciting news around here for ages.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: It’s no big deal. 39. 46  Blue (10-12-2012) 40.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE BOWEN
dialogues.text: No big deal? Sheesh, there’s a guy living the life of Reilly -- a million here, a million there. Why, the newspaper’s going to do a big write-up on you!

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’1l get my picture in the paper?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE BOWEN
dialogues.text: You bet you will! David is beginning to realize that there’s little use try to stop this train. A BUS turns onto the street and approaches the curb.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad, here’s the bus.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE BOWEN
dialogues.text: Okay, well, good seein’ you there, Woody. We’re all real happy for you and real pleased you thought to stop back home and share the big news.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE BOWEN
dialogues.text: Watch your wallet!

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER --
dialogues.text: Kate gets off the bus and examines Woody’s bandaged foreh

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You both look like hell.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Like hell you are. You look like an old drunk. You’re lucky you’re not dead.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I haven't been drinking.  41.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That’s what you said on our first date. (to David) And you, have you gone bananas? Almost getting your father killed over some cockamamie pot of gold. As the bus departs, David takes his mother’s elbow and le her a few steps away from Woody.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Listen, go easy, okay? You and I both know it’s not about the money. It’s about...you know, how much longer is he going to be around -- at least semi-coherently? What’s the harm in letting him have his little fantasy for a couple more days?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You and Ross always fretting over your father. What about me? How about taking me out to see my sister in Eau Claire? Your father doesn’t even know what the hell’s going on around him half the time. (turning) Do you, Woody?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Do I what?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Know what’s going on around you. Woody’s unsure how to answer -- he looks at her, looks ar the depot area, then back at her.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to David) You watch it, or that’s what you’re going to turn into. Now take me to the cemetery. I want to pay my respects.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Martha said she’d have lunch ready.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Martha can wait. Kate marches away. David thinks better of arguing.  Blue (10-12-2012) 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flowers in hand, Kate offers a running commentary as she leads Woody and David slowly past the headstones.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That’s Woody’s mother Sara. She hated me because she wanted him to marry someone who’d milk the cows, but I said I ain’t fiddlin’ with no cow titties. I’m a city girl. The good lord did not do Sara any favors in the looks department. More a man’s face than a woman's, really. I was pretty, so she resented me. You knew your mother was ugly, right, Woody? Woody looks at Kate, then stares at his mother’s grave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How did she die?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Saw herself in the mirror one day! No, cancer. (moving on) And there’s the old Swede Tolf. A good man, your grandpa. Never said much. That farm just ruined him. (to Woody) You're lucky I took you away from there. Woody nods slightly as he looks at his father’s leaf-cove grave.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s Woody’s brother David. You were named after him. He died of scarlet fever when he was only two. Woody slept in the same bed with him but never got it. David contemplates the sight of his own name on a headsto

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here’s Woody’s little sister Rose. She was only nineteen when she got killed in a car wreck near Wausa. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What a whore. I liked Rose, but my God, she was a slut.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mom, come on.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I’m just telling the truth. She was screwing guys in back of the Hawthorne Creamery when she was only... (a whisper) ...fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Where’s your family?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: They’re over at the Catholic cemetery. We’ll go there later. Catholics wouldn’t be caught dead around all these damn Lutherans. Now there’s Delmer, Woody’s cousin. He was a drunk. One time we were wrastlin’ and he felt me up. Grabbed a handful of boob, and Woody was right there and didn’t have a clue, did you, Woody?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: My goodness, I didn’t know Keith White was here. When did he die? Keith White. He wanted in my pants too, but oh, he was so boring. Hearing enough, Woody and David head toward the car. Kate remains at Keith’s grave and pulls her dress up.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See what you could’ve had, Keith, if you hadn’t talked about wheat all the time? INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S KITCHEN - DAY 48 Kate and Martha talk while Ray and Woody sit silent.  Blue (10-12-2012) 44,

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Peggy got knocked up again? At her age? That old cow must be fifty.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: She just looks fifty. That’s what pig farming will do to you. 49 EXT. RAY AND MARTHA’S PORCH - DAY 49 David sits with his cousins Cole and Bart. No one speaks a moment. Then --

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: You got any other cars?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, just that one.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: What’s the engine?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It’s, uh, a four-cylinder.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Yeah, but what size?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don’t really know.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: What’s your brother drive?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Who, Ross?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, what’s he drive?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He has a Kia Sedona, and Marcie’s got a Nissan Pathfinder. She carts the kids around a lot.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: So you all got Jap cars?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Actually, Kia is Korean.  50 51 52 Blue (10-12-2012) 45. This clarification is met with a hostile, blank stare. * Just then a HIGH SCHOOL KID with a camera pulls up on a bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL KID
dialogues.text: Hey, is this where I can find Mr. Woody Grant?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Who wants to know?

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL KID
dialogues.text: I was sent by Mrs. Nagy over at the Hawthorne Republican to take his * picture.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Come on in. He’s right inside.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL KID
dialogues.text: And they want him to be sure to come by the office for an interview.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: (opening the screen door) Hey, Uncle Woody! EXT. RAY AND MARTHA’S FRONT YARD - DAY 50

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: looking directly into the camera with a grin on his face.

dialogues.speaker: THE HIGH SCHOOL KID
dialogues.text: focuses and shoots as the other Grants watch from the por

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: looks concerned. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David parks his car and heads inside of the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a small office. Except for a few computers, it could 1960. An older woman -- PEG NAGY -- types at a desk.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Mrs. Nagy?  Blue (10-12-2012)

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m David Grant, Woody’s son.

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: Well, I’m very pleased to meet you. Your father is certainly quite the celebrity around here. Did Parker show up to take his picture?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s what I came to tell you about. Dad didn’t win any lottery or sweepstakes or anything. He’s a little confused about something he got in the mail, and it’s gotten way out of hand.

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: So he didn’t win a million dollars?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: Just goes to show you some things never change. He was always a little confused.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You know my dad?

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: It’s all ancient history, of course, and I don’t want to speak out of turn, but Woody and I used to go together.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You were his girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: Your mother is what happened. How is Kate? 46.  Blue (10-12-2012) 46a.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fine. She’s here too.  47.

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: You tell her Peg Bender says hello.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: She won't slap me, will she?

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: Why would she? She won. David looks at her. She smiles wistfully.

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Water under the bridge. Don’t get me wrong, I married a wonderful man -- we ran this paper together until he died -- had three children, eight grandchildren. I’ve got no complaints.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Was he drinking back then?

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: Of course he was. It happens early around here. There isn’t much else to do. Nowadays, of course, it’s not just booze but all that other stuff. For Woody it got bad after Korea. He had a hard time over there.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I thought he was just a mechanic.

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: Oh, he was, for the army planes. But he was shot down while being transferred. You knew that, right? David looks at her with a puzzled expression.

dialogues.speaker: LATER --
dialogues.text: Peg leafs through a bound newspaper archive from the 1950

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here it is. Woody, Verne, and Albert. A HEADLINE reads “Grant Boys Return from the Fight” above photos of 20-year-old Woody and two of his brothers.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They look like kids.  53 54 Blue (10-12-2012) 48.

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: Your dad was never much of a talker, and when he came back he hardly said a word. But always very kind. People took advantage of him. He couldn’t turn down a favor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, now that everyone thinks he’s a millionaire, he’s a big hero around here.

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I can’t print that he is, but I won’t print that he isn’t either. I’11 just do a little story on him and Kate stopping through town.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hard to imagine you and my mother fighting over the same man.

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: I knew I didn’t have a chance anyway.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: PEG NAGY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t let him round the bases. David takes in this woman, wonders for a moment what he'd like if this woman had been his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing. It’s Karaoke night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Someone's the other his parents sit at a table reading their menus. singing at the little stage near the salad bar in room.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What’re you having, old man?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Meat loaf.  Blue (10-12-2012) 49,

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You been staring at the menu for ten minutes. Where does it say meat loaf?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: They should have meat loaf.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Well, they don’t, so pick something else. The WAITRESS appears.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Are we ready to order?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad, do you know what you want?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Do you have meat loaf? Kate rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: No, I’m sorry, we don’t. That's only on the lunch buffet.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Chicken then.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Did you want the fried chicken, or the flame-broiled chicken breast?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Fried.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: He’1l have the flame-broiled.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: And you, ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I was thinking of having the roast beef, but now I’m not sure. What do you recommend? What’s good here?  Blue (10-12-2012) 50.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Well, it’s all good, but I’m real partial to the tilapia.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No, I want the roast beef.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I‘ll have the tilapia.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Don’t forget to help yourselves to the soup-and-salad bar. She leaves. Just then -- a new VOICE starts singing.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Oh my God, that’s Ed Pegram singing. They look over and see Ed. He’s not great, but not bad.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Maybe we should go ask for the compressor.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: He’1ll give it back.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: He always had a nice voice. It was the only nice thing about that bastard.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: He’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: All right? Did you know he was always trying to get in my bloomers?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mom, was the whole town trying to seduce you?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: These boys grow up staring at the rear ends of cows and pigs. It’s only natural that a real woman’s going to get them chafing their pants.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mom, please don’t talk about that kind of stuff right before we eat.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (softening) Oh, you were always such a sensitive boy. And such a beautiful boy. Why, when you were a baby, people used to stop me on the street and tell me how beautiful you were. A lot of them thought you were a girl. Isn’t that right, Woody -- people used to stop me on the street to say how beautiful David was?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I dunno. Ed Pegram pauses singing to make an announcement.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Hey, everybody, we've got a celebrity here -- my old friend and the rich man you've all been hearing about -- Woody Grant. Woody, take a bow! The other diners applaud. Woody looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Stand up, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Don’t encourage this nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad, stand up. It’s for you.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Just do it and get it over with. Woody stands and realizes the growing applause is for him He turns to look at everyone, enjoying this once-in-a- lifetime experience.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Roslyn, you'll be getting a big tip from that table tonight!  55 Blue (10-12-2012) 52.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Okay, you ham, that’s enough. She tugs him back down into the booth.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: And Kate, I guess that makes you a millionairess! Why don’t you take a bow too, Katesy-Kate? Kate rolls her eyes before getting up and going through t motions. At first polite, she soon allows herself to bask

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is washing his hands when Ed Pegram enters.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Hey there, little Davey. I was hoping to run into you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, big Ed. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: I want you to know I think the world of Woody. Always a good man.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Heart of gold. No secret, though, Woody drank quite a bit when we had the garage. Messed up a lot of jobs and let a lot of money walk. He was older than me, kind of like a big brother, Korea vet, the whole nine yards. I wanted to show him some respect, and I loaned him a ton of dough I never saw again. So seeing as how he’s come into some cash lately, some no-foolin’-around cash he didn’t even have to work for, seems to me it'd only be fair to settle up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You want your $800 back?

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Woody owes me a lot more than that.  56 53.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to break it to you, but my dad didn’t actually win anything. It’s all a big misunderstanding. You know Woody. You can understand that.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Right, so you’re all headed to Lincoln to visit the roller-skating museum. Look, Davey, I really don’t want to bring a lawyer in on this.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Lawyer? What’s the statute of limitations on bullshit? Ed lays an arm on David's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: I’m a man with a real strong sense of right and wrong. And if Woody hit it rich and I don’t see any of it, well, that’s wrong. And I will make it right.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Are you threatening my family? Ed withdraws his arm and grins.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Threatening? No, that would be wrong. Hey, I’m the victim here. Just food for thought. Now, if you'll excuse me, I got to take a leak real bad. You know beer -- you just rent the stuff. Ed takes a stand at the ice-filled urinal. David leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David returns to find his parents finishing a conversatio with old friends DALE AND KATHY SLAASTED.

dialogues.speaker: DALE
dialogues.text: Great to see you again, Woody. We're real happy for you. Buy a boat and go fishin’ -- that’s what I'd do.  54.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I just might.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: David, you probably don’t remember Kathy and Dale Slaasted.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Oh, David Grant, I never would have recognized you in a million years, how you’ve grown. You were such a beautiful little boy.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I keep telling him. (to David) You see?

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Like a little prince made out of porcelain.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KATHY
dialogues.text: Okay now. You all take care. Enjoy spending the loot. The Slaasteds leave. David sits.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I just had an interesting conversation with Ed Pegram in the men’s room.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What did he want?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Some of Dad’s money.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Lord almighty, that man’s brain keeps getting smaller, and his balls keep getting bigger.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I can lend him a couple of bucks if he’s hard up.  57 58 Blue (10-12-2012) 55.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Like hell you will. EXT. RAY AND MARTHA’S HOUSE - NIGHT 57 Establishing. INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S SPARE BEDROOM - NIGHT 58 David wakes up, needing a moment to realize where he is - a trundle bed beneath the bed where his parents lie aslee He sits up and watches them, wondering who these people assigned to be his parents really are, and how absurd it for a 40-year-old man to be sleeping next to his parents. He lies back down and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT MORNING --
dialogues.text: Hair disheveled and face unshaven, Woody, looks into came

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Wake up. Hey you, wake up. Wake up now. David groggily comes to, coughing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What’s up, Dad? What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Are we going to Lincoln today?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Why not today?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Today’s Sunday. Lincoln’s closed. And all your brothers are coming over today, remember?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Some of them are dead.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The dead ones won't be here.  Blue (10-12-2012) 56.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Oh. But goddammit, if I don’t get to that money, they'll give it to somebody else! David crawls out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Say, Dad, do you remember a gal you used to go out with named Peg Bender?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Last week. What do you mean when? Years ago, before you were married. Peg Bender.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Why? Woody looks at the ground, then turns to leave. WOODY (CONT’D) That was a long time ago. What’re you bringing that up for? 59 INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S LIVING ROOM - DAY 59 A pro football game is on TV. David sits among Woody and five of his BROTHERS -- Ray, VERNE, CARL, CECIL, and ALBERT, all in their 60s and 70s. A couple of other male COUSINS are there too -- one named RANDY -- but no Cole and Bart. 60 INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S KITCHEN - DAY 60 The kitchen is abuzz as the Grant wives prepare supper -- Kate, Aunt Martha, AUNT BETTY and AUNT FLO. Maybe there’s another middle-aged DAUGHTER OR TWO.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT BETTY
dialogues.text: I didn’t see your boys out there, Martha. Where are Cole and Bart?  57.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oh, they’re out volunteering today. Picking up trash out by the highway.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT BETTY
dialogues.text: That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: They’11 be back for supper.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It’s community service. On account of Cole’s rape.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Sex assault. Not rape.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What’s the difference?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: There’s a big difference. Cole can explain it better than I can. And Bart doesn’t have to be there. He’s volunteering.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FLO
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s nice. 61 INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S LIVING ROOM - DAY 61 The men continue sipping their beers in front of the TV.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: Verne, you still drive that Chevy?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VERNE
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: The Chevy. That Impala you used to have.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VERNE
dialogues.text: I never had an Impala.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: Hell, I don’t know what it was then. Silence as they watch an incomplete pass.  58.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VERNE
dialogues.text: I had a Buick.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: That’s what it was. You still driving that?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VERNE
dialogues.text: I haven’t had that for years.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: I thought you still had it. David blinks in disbelief at this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE CECIL
dialogues.text: That was a ‘78, wasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE CECIL
dialogues.text: ‘79. Those were good cars.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VERNE
dialogues.text: It was okay.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: They don’t make ‘em like that anymore. Those cars’1ll run forever. Whatever happened to it?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VERNE
dialogues.text: Stopped runnin’.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: Well, they’1l do that. A knock on the front door. UNCLE RAY (CONT’D) Come in. David’s brother Ross enters.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Hey, everybody.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Hi, Ross. The other uncles and cousins chime in with grunted hellos although no one gets up. Ross turns his attention to the  Blue (10-12-2012) 59.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How about Marcie and the kids?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Dance recital. Who’s playing?

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN RANDY
dialogues.text: Philadelphia-Miami.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How long did it take you to drive? All turn their heads to Ross, waiting for the answer. 62 INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S KITCHEN - DAY 62 It continues.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Sharon’s kids are always in trouble. And she’s gotten really big -- she’s gotta be at least -- no offense, Betty -- how much does your Beverly weigh?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT BETTY
dialogues.text: About one-ninety.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Well, I guess she’s around that, but you know she has a much smaller frame so it really shows up on her.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You’re not serious.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m serious, you should see her. She is fat. 63 INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S DINING ROOM - DAY 63 The extended family eat elbow-to-elbow around the table. Cole and Bart have returned.

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN RANDY
dialogues.text: So Uncle Woody, you talk to the newspaper yet?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Not yet, but they had a kid come by and take my picture.  Blue (10-12-2012) 60.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I went by the office, gave ‘em the lowdown.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FLO
dialogues.text: What’s it like being a millionaire, Woody?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FLO
dialogues.text: A million dollars. Can you beat that?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VERNE
dialogues.text: Let’s all raise a glass to Woody and Kate here. They unceremoniously clink their glasses and beers togeth and resume eating. Ross looks at Kate, who rolls her eyes helpless to fight the tide.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Not trying to be a spoil-sport here, but you all know this is bull, right? My dad didn’t win anything.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Nice try, Ross.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: We're way beyond that.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (almost contrite) Ross is right. He didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT BETTY
dialogues.text: Trying to keep it quiet so everybody don’t come looking for a handout, huh, Kate? Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE CECIL
dialogues.text: No, that’s right. Woody’s not a millionaire yet. Let’s all remember that. But tomorrow’s a different story.  61.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FLO
dialogues.text: What’s the first thing you’re going to do with the money? The very first thing.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Get a truck. And a compressor.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE VERNE
dialogues.text: What the hell you want with a compressor?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I need it to paint.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT BETTY
dialogues.text: Are you still working, Woody?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He just needs to replace the compressor Ed Pegram stole.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE CECIL
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just get it back from him while you’re here in town?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You think he still has it?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT MARTHA
dialogues.text: That fool never gets rid of nothing. He’s got a barn full of junk.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: David. Let’s go get it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad, you want to get your old compressor back?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t care.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You boys will do no such thing. Get yourselves shot for an old piece of garbage. Am I the only sane one in this family?  64 62.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But hey, Ross, I was thinking we could take a drive later to see Dad’s old house, the old Grant house.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Is it still there?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RAY
dialogues.text: Dan Conway farms the place, but he never tore it down. It’s still sittin’ there.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Why would you want to waste your time seeing that? Must be filled with rats.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad, would you like to take a drive later to see the old homestead?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: David and I want to see where you grew up.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: What for? EXT. RAY AND MARTHA’S HOUSE - DAY 64 The relatives sit on the porch. Albert sits in a chair ne the street. Ross and David wander out onto the front yard

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What’s Uncle Albert doing?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Watching cars go by. They look -- there are no cars.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember when they came up to visit when we were kids, and he’d take a chair out in the front yard every evening to watch the road?  Blue (10-12-2012) 63. Aunt Betty approaches with son RANDY. Behind them Bart an Cole amble down the porch stairs but for the moment maint a respectful distance.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT BETTY
dialogues.text: It sure is good to see you boys again. We really can’t let so much time pass again.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Thanks, Aunt Betty. Great to see you too.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT BETTY
dialogues.text: You know, there’s something that’s hard to bring up, but we think it deserves mentioning.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What’s that? Aunt Betty seems uncomfortable, so Randy takes the lead.

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN RANDY
dialogues.text: You may not know it, but Uncle Woody used to have a lot of money problems, and family members would help him out from time to time. So in light of his good fortune, well, we thought your family might want to make things right.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
