dialogues.text: (glancing at Ross) I’ve been hearing that a lot lately.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: You know, Cole’s and my folks wouldn’t never say nothin’ if it was just for them. But they’re gonna need in on this deal too.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Are you saying you want money from us?

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN RANDY
dialogues.text: We just figured that seein’ how the family helped Woody out and all, kind of kept him on his feet...  Blue (10-12-2012) 64.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT BETTY
dialogues.text: Verne and I loaned Woody quite a bit, and it wasn’t like we was rich. But he was my brother-in- law, and we couldn’t bear to see your family suffer.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Aunt Betty, guys, look. Honestly, for real. Woody didn’t win anything. It’s a total sham.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: You’re a damn liar!

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Don’t feed us any of your bullshit, Ross.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: You wanna go?

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Let’s do it! Ross and Cole make at each other like roosters, pushing a shoving. All the other relatives look, even Uncle Albert, now twisting around in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Just watch the face, okay? I’m on TV.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (rushing over) What’s going on? Have you boys lost your minds?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Aunt Betty and her henchmen here are asking for reparations.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: They’re after Dad’s “winnings.” They say he owes them money.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: See? There is money.  65.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Owes them money? What on Earth are you talking about, Betty?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT BETTY
dialogues.text: Now, Kate, you know we used to help you and Woody out when he was drinking up everything he earned.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You know as well as I do it was the other way around. You were always having him work on your cars for free, getting free gas --

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN RANDY
dialogues.text: Aunt Kate, we’re not asking for much. Just a token.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I kept records. The money you gave him didn’t come close to what you owed. He couldn’t say no to anybody, and it ruined him.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT BETTY
dialogues.text: I think you’re having a senior moment here, Kate. Where do you think all that money come from when you got a bee in your bonnet to move to Billings and open a salon?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: From my folks when they croaked, that’s where! I can’t believe the nerve of you people. Usually a person has to die before the vultures start circling.

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN RANDY
dialogues.text: Calm down, Aunt Katie. We didn’t mean nothin’ by it. We was just doing you a courtesy before we talk to Woody direct.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Don’t you dare think about asking that poor man for money.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: He ain’t poor. He’s rich.  65 66 Blue (10-12-2012) 66.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Even if he was, he wouldn’t give you a blessed penny. I'd put my foot down.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Maybe it ain’t up to you, Aunt Kate.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That’s enough! You listen real good! You can all just... (leaning in) .»..go fuck yourselves! A stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Ross and David) Boys, get your dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The late afternoon is overcast and windy. Ross’s car moves slowly up a dirt driveway toward a dilapidated two-story house on the verge of collapse. All the windows are gone or broken. Weeds and bushes grow tal around it. David, Kate and Ross get out. Last to emerge is Woody, wh remains next to the car looking at where he grew up. They walk up the porch steps and, amid lots of flies, for open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inside is a wreck. Still, the floors are solid.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you think, old man?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Looks about the same.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That’s true. This is about how your mother kept it.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: My dad built it.  Blue (10-12-2012) 67.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Really? You mean by himself?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Before I was born. His brothers helped. Woody walks to a bedroom and peers in from the doorway. WOODY (CONT’D) This was my room.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That’s where Woody’s brother David died.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Ross) Scarlet fever. Dad slept with him in the same bed. (to Woody) Do you remember that, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I was there.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: How old were you?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Why’d they let him sleep with you?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: They didn’t know what it was.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You were lucky you never got it.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I guess. Woody tests the wooden stairway, then walks --

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS -
dialogues.text: The others follow. The roof has holes, and the patchy floorboards are warped. Woody enters --

dialogues.speaker: A BEDROOM -
dialogues.text: 67 Blue (10-12-2012) 68. WOODY (CONT’D) This was my parents’ room. I’d get whipped if they found me in here. (taking it in) Guess nobody’s going to whip me now. He goes to a wall opens a closet and peers inside.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My dad built all of this.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Tolf was good with his hands, all right. I wish our home was built half as good. Woody walks to a window and points outside.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: The barn’s still standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody stands alone at the edge of a field, lost in though David approaches but stops just behind Woody, allowing hi father a moment. Then --

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Seen enough?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I suppose. It’s just a bunch of old wood and some weeds. Neither moves. WOODY (CONT’D) Over there’s where I found the hail adjuster’s knife.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: The hail adjuster come out after a storm. Cecil and me and my dad went over there with him and he cut off some oats to check ‘em for hail damage. But they were too damaged. Said he wouldn’t pay.  Blue (10-12-2012) 69.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Said it must’ve been something besides hail done that, but he just didn’t want to pay.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How could he get away with that?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Oh, they was all cheap, lyin’ bastards. So when we started back, I saw his knife there, and I picked it up and took it to him. My dad was ready to kill me. Said the moron didn’t deserve to have his knife back. They look out across the field of corn stubble.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did you ever want to farm like your dad?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t remember. It doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What happened when your parents died? Did you kids sell the place?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Wasn't ours.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Whose was it?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Some banker owned it. We just rented.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Your dad built a house on land he didn’t own?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: We had to sleep somewhere.  68 Blue (10-12-2012) 70.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: If you could do it all over, would you have stayed out here and farmed? Woody suddenly sets out toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Can’t do it all over. Can’t do none of it over. INT. ROSS’S CAR - RURAL ROAD - DAY 68 Ross and David sit up front. Headed back to town, they dr past more farms.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: There’s the O’Hare farm. She’s dead. He’s in a nursing home in Valentine. One of their little brats still lives there. Oh, and that’s Ed Pegram’s place on the right. Ross hits the brakes.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What‘re you doing? Once the car stops, he and David look at the house and at each other.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let’s do it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: We're right here.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What are you boys up to now?

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: We're just going to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You’re asking for trouble.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad, don’t you want to see if he still has your compressor? Woody twists his head around, trying to figure out what’s going on. Ross reverses and then heads up the driveway.  69 70 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car stops. Ross and David emerge and walk up to the front door. David knocks. Moments later they walk to the BARN. Woody and Kate watch from the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What in the hell are they doing? (yelling out the window) Will you two knock off this foolishness? David opens the barn door, and the two of them go inside. Moments later they come out lugging a rusty old air compressor. Ross opens the back of the car. They put the compressor inside, jump in the car, and Ross speeds away. INT. ROSS’S CAR - RURAL ROAD - DAY 70 Beaming and out of breath, David turns around to Woody.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad, you finally got your compressor back.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: That’s not my compressor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sure it is.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Mine didn’t look anything like that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It has to be yours. It’s an old compressor we found in Ed Pegram’s barn.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: That wasn’t Ed’s barn.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: That’s the Westendorf place.  Blue (10-12-2012) 72.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s right. Ross slows the car.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right, the Pegrams live closer to town. I got confused. Ed and his wife Dorothy. God, what a pig she was.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Anything you want to say about the Westendorfs?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No, they’re good folks. Releasing a loud exhale, Ross looks at David and starts turning the car around.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They had some tough times. Lost a child. Almost went broke, but they worked hard and saved the farm. Salt of the earth, the Westendorfs. They really didn’t deserve you boys doing that to them.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Woody) Why didn’t you tell us that wasn’t Ed’s house?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I didn’t know what the hell you were doing.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen us steal machinery before?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I never know what you boys are up to.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you say it wasn’t yours?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted it.  71 EXT. Blue (10-12-2012) 73.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Why would we want an old compressor?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: That’s what I couldn’t figure out.

dialogues.speaker: FARMHOUSE
dialogues.text: Back in the driveway, David and Ross return the compresso into the barn. Meanwhile, another CAR comes up the driveway. GEORGE AND JEAN WESTENDORF get out and approach Ross’s car to find W and Kate in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Hi, George. Hi, Jean. Remember us? Kate and Woody Grant?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE WESTENDORF
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. How you doin’?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Just fine. We were passing by, so we thought we’d stop in. Haven’t been in Hawthorne for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN WESTENDORF
dialogues.text: What are you doing in the back seat?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Oh, we just thought we’d rest back here until you showed up.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN WESTENDORF
dialogues.text: Would you like to come in?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Sorry, but we just have time to say hi and get going.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE WESTENDORF
dialogues.text: Hi there, Woody. How's it goin’?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Fine. How’re you, George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE WESTENDORF
dialogues.text: Getting by. You still up there in Montana?  72 73 74 75 Blue (10-12-2012) 74.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE WESTENDORF
dialogues.text: Billings, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN WESTENDORF
dialogues.text: Still doing hair out there, Kate?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No, I let that go. They all stare at one another.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE WESTENDORF
dialogues.text: (slapping the car) Well, good to see you folks.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I'd better get up front and drive us back to town. She gets out, says goodbye to the Westendorfs, and climbs the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through cracks in the door, Ross and David watch the Westendorfs head inside the house as Kate sloppily maneuv the car down the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as the Westendorfs close their door, Ross and David sprinting out of the barn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car rolls slowly down the gravel road. Ross and David burst out of the bushes. The car stops, and the boys clim inside. INT. ROSS’S CAR - RURAL ROAD - DAY 75 Ross sits next to Kate up front, David in the back with Woody.  76 77 Blue (10-12-2012) 75.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You were right, Mom. The Westendorfs look like real nice people.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I tried to tell you. What do you want to do now, bust into a silo and steal some corn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Woody sit across from each other in a booth. Wo finishes a beer, David a Mountain Dew.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: What time we gettin’ on the road tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think eight sounds about right. Woody nods.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want another beer?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I suppose. Suddenly a slightly drunk Ed Pegram shoves David over and takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Hey there, Davey-boy, make room. How’s it going, cowboy?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It was going fine.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Woody.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Well, enough of this chit-chat. Time to get down to business. Woody, I tried to tell your boy here you wouldn’t mind using some of your winnings to even the score with your old pal Ed. Woody pulls out his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: How much do you need? I gota twenty.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: A twenty? Oh, no, no, no, no. I was thinkin’ more along the lines of, say, ten grand.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Give him ten grand, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t got it yet.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Woody, I always thought we was friends. Remember, I was the one who convinced you to stay with Kate. Huh? ED PEGRAM (CONT’D) Oh yeah, Davey. Your old man was thinking of getting a divorce because he was screwing some half- breed from the reservation. Thought he was in love. Ain’t that right, Woody? Woody stares at the table.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: When was this?

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: After Ross was born. Before you. Hell, if it wasn’t for me, you probably wouldn't be here. Back then divorce was a sin. Now I guess it’s okay. God must have changed his mind or something. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Although I didn’t really blame you, Woody, considering Kate’s such a bitch. David glares at Ed as though he could hit him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Get the hell away from us.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: I want that money.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Move.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: Okay, little Davey. Have it your way. But this is the last time Eddie-boy plays nice. Ed gets up and strolls out of the tavern as though making little show of it. David looks at Woody, who continues to stare at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody and David leave the tavern and head to the car. Suddenly TWO MEN WEARING HOODS run up from behind, grab W and David and shove them to the ground. One of the men reaches into Woody’s jacket and grabs the sweepstakes envelope before they run off into the dark.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: They took my letter. David climbs to his feet to help his father. EXT. RAY AND MARTHA’S HOUSE - NIGHT 79 David guides an unsteady Woody toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hold on a second. Don’t move. David goes over and puts his hand on the hood of Cole and Bart’s pick-up. Then he looks up at the light in their bedroom.  Blue (10-12-2012) 80 INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S HOUSE UPSTAIRS - NIGHT David knocks on a Cole’s door. Bart opens it. pornography on his computer -- we can hear it.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Where’s what?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just give it back.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: Don’t know what you’re talking about, buddy. Bart, do you know?

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Course not.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Where is it? Finally --

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: We don’t got it.

dialogues.speaker: BART
dialogues.text: Shut the hell up, Cole.

dialogues.speaker: COLE
dialogues.text: We tossed it when we saw how bogus it was. Millionaire. What a joke. You people are pathetic. 78. 80 Cole watches David nods slowly, turns and shuts the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BART, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fuck him.

dialogues.speaker: COLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lying to us like we’re a bunch of idiots. 81 EXT. RAY AND MARTHA’S LIVING ROOM AND DINING ROOM - NI David wanders through the first floor looking for his fat

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad? Dad? Finally David turns on the light inside the -- INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS A82 -- where he finds that Woody has been sitting in the dark the kitchen table, utterly dejected, drinking a glass of milk.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I won’t mention any of this to Mom or Ross. We’1ll just tell them you came to your senses, and we'll head back home. Sound good? It’s okay - - at least we’ve had a little change of scenery. I’m happy we got this time together. Aren’t you? Woody doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? (off Woody’s silence) You know they weren’t going to give you that money, right? Woody can’t respond, can’t move. David looks at him, lets out a long sigh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe they dropped it. Should we go have a look? Woody stands up, grabs his coat, and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Woody search along the street and sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think it was easier to find your teeth. He watches his father, tireless at his task.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, let’s take a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As David and Woody enter, Ed Pegram is standing by the ba reading the sweepstakes letter out loud for the benefit o other patrons.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM
dialogues.text: “Congratulations, Woodrow T. Grant. You may have won one million dollars.” Big laughter.  84 80. ED PEGRAM (CONT’D) “Just imagine what you could do with one million dollars, Woodrow.” We know what the son of a bitch would do -- buy a truck! More laughter. Woody remains impassive, but we can see humiliation in his eyes. ED PEGRAM (CONT’D) “All you need to do to collect your prize is return this letter to our office, along with your winning prize number and a list of the magazine subscriptions you’d like to -- The room has grown silent. Ed looks up and joins the othe staring at Woody and David.

dialogues.speaker: ED PEGRAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, Woody, I was just lookin’ for you. Somebody found your precious sweepstakes notice out on the street. Woody slowly approaches to retrieve the letter. ED PEGRAM (CONT’D) You should take better care of that, buddy. Wouldn’t want to lose it again. Woody carefully folds the letter and puts it back in his pocket. Then he walks slowly toward the door as David goe up to Ed. After a few moments of staring at Ed, David turns away. T he stops, doubles back, and PUNCHES Ed in the face as har he can. Ed falls onto a stool and hugs it as he falls to the floo David walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk toward David’s car, Woody seems dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Blue (10-12-2012) 81. Woody starts walking again but soon stumbles, reaching ou David for support.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad, what’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Just a little dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We'd better get you to a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Just get me back to the house. We’re going to Lincoln in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, we aren’t.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Yes, we are.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, this does it. This is where it stops.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: You promised.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Your head’s busted open, and now you can barely stand up.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’m still going.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Goddammit! You didn’t win! Can‘t you get that through your head? You did not win anything! And we're not driving all the way to Lincoln over a stupid fantasy! It’s my own damn fault for bringing you this far! Woody slumps against a building, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've got enough money to get by. You can’t drive. What’s the point?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I want a truck.  82.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why do you need a truck so bad?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Just to have it. I always wanted a brand new truck.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What about the rest of the money? You don’t need a million dollars for a damn pickup truck. Woody is still turned away.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: That money’s for you boys. I wanted to leave you something.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We're fine, Dad. We don’t need it.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I just want to leave you something. David approaches his father.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You know if there was any chance you won, I’d take you. You know that, right?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t lie to you.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The only reason I agreed to take you to Lincoln was to get out of Billings for a while and maybe have some time with you. And to get you to shut up.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: All right what?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’1l shut up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What about Lincoln? A short pause before --

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: We don’t have to go. David sees that Woody is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let’s get you to a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I ain’t going to another goddamn hospital. INT. DAVID’S CAR - NIGHT A85 Woody is collapsed against the passenger window as David rushes him to -- NORFOLK -— -- where a sign announces this town of 25,000 people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody is propped up on pillows, an IV in his arm. Kate an Ross sit watching him sleep. David is in the hall finishing a conversation with a DOCT then enters.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They can keep him here until tomorrow afternoon or so. Then I guess we'll just start driving home. Probably see you Tuesday night.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks, David. Mom and I will get an early start tomorrow morning. I got to get back.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: And I’m going to have to listen to him harp about losing out on his fortune for the rest of his life. Or my life. He’s going to bury me at this rate.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You guys go ahead and get some sleep. I’11 stay with him tonight.  86 87 88 89 90 Blue (10-12-2012) 84. Ross and Kate stand up. Kate approaches the bed, straight Woody’s wild hair, and kisses his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You big idiot. Ross and Kate leave. David sits in the big hospital chair and presses the TV remote at Woody’s bedside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David wakes up and sees that Woody’s bed is empty. INT. DAVID’S CAR - OUTSKIRTS OF NORFOLK - EARLY MORNING 8 Overcast. Through David’s windshield, we drive a short while before finding Woody -- hospital gown flapping beneath his jacke up ahead walking on the shoulder of a road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody walks along the shoulder, just like how we found hi the beginning of the film. David’s car passes Woody, pulls over and comes to a stop. David gets out and looks at his father.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: All right. Let’s go to Lincoln. Woody walks to the passenger side and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David drives while Woody sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: LATER --
dialogues.text: Woody rubs the sweepstakes letter slowly between his fing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crude SIGN outside reads LEECHES AND CRAWLERS.  91 92 93 94 Blue (10-12-2012) 85. David exits the store and hands Woody a tall-boy of beer paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our heros pass a sign reading “LINCOLN CITY LIMITS” and exchange a look of satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STATE CAPITOL BUILDING towers in the distance as the crosses a viaduct into Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: LATER --
dialogues.text: The car makes its way through busy DOWNTOWN LINCOLN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David stops the car in the lot of a low-rent industrial p of what seem like oversized garages. They get out and stand looking at their long-sought destination -- “Mid-Plains Marketing Promotions.” David notices that Woody still has his hospital gown on, he helps him take it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the no-nonsense front office and find a middle aged RECEPTIONIST. An open door beyond her looks into a small warehouse/work area.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Hi. Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My father is here to collect his million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Show her your letter, Dad. Woody extracts the tattered sacred document from his pock and hands it over. She looks at it and types quickly on h computer.  Blue (10-12-2012) 86.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but your number wasn’t one of the winning numbers. David looks at Woody, who doesn’t seem to understand.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Looks like you didn’t win.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: But it says I won.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: It says you won if your number is the winning number. I’m afraid it isn’t. Woody looks at her blankly. RECEPTIONIST (CONT’D) I’m sorry, sir. I hope you didn’t have to come too far.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Montana.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Oh, my.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, Dad, I guess that’s it.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I can give you a free gift, like a hat or a seat cushion.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do you want a hat or a seat cushion?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do you want a hat or a seat cushion?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: A hat.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He’1l take the hat.  Blue (10-12-2012) 87. The receptionist slides her chair out, goes to the corner behind her desk, and retrieves a hat out of one of two la boxes. The hat reads, “Prize Winner!” Woody puts it on, turns and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does this happen a lot?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Every once in a while. Usually older people like your father. Does he have Alzheimer’s or some other dementia?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He just believes stuff that people tell him.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s too bad.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David gets in the driver’s seat of his car and finds Wood hat on, eyes closed, head tipped back. He looks dead.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Dad? Dad?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We're going back to Billings, okay?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Okay. Woody nods. David has a thought.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We might make a couple quick stops first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David negotiates with a SALEWMAN while Woody, wearing his hat, waits outside.  97 Blue (10-12-2012) 88. David eventually comes out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay, Dad, we're all set. Help me get our stuff out of the car. David finishes putting their belongings inside the bed of PICKUP TRUCK.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I don’t understand what happened to your car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They made me a real good offer for it.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Wasn’t much of a car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, this truck’s a real step up. Only five years old. Practically brand new. Oh, I hope you don’t mind -- I put your name on the title. After a few seconds --

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: The truck’s in my name, you say?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But you’re going to have to let me drive it.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: You work something out with those prize people? David takes a long look at his father, wondering how to respond. EXT.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah. They were willing to go as far as a truck.

dialogues.speaker: SEARS HOMEWTOWN STORE
dialogues.text: This is a smaller Sears that specializes in appliances. 97  98 99 100 101 102 Blue (10-12-2012) 89. Woody watches as David and a CLERK hoist a box containing NEW AIR COMPRESSOR into the back of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As David drives, Woody plays with all the new knobs and buttons on the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David pulls off the highway and curiously heads back towa HAWTHORNE.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: What’re we going back to Hawthorne for?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just got one last quick thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the late afternoon, and the sun is low. David brings the truck to a stop at the top of Main Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David turns to his father.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Your turn to drive.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: You said I couldn’t.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just drive it down Locust Street. It’s only a couple of blocks. There’s no traffic. Woody looks out the windshield at his old town, then back David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David gets out and opens the passenger door for Woody. Wo walks around to the driver’s side.  103 104 105 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody gets comfortable and sets the mirrors before shifti the transmission into Drive. He takes his foot off the brake, and the truck starts to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the pickup cruises slowly down Main Street, Bernie Bow from the bus station spots Woody and gives a big thumbs-u

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE BOWEN
dialogues.text: Hey there, Woody! Looking good!

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: (to David) Get down.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I said get down.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay. David obeys and ducks below the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER --
dialogues.text: Ed Pegram comes out of the Blinker Tavern, sporting a bla eye. He watches Woody pass.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER --
dialogues.text: Peg Nagy comes out of the Cedar County Record office, key hand to lock up. She looks over, and Woody and she lock e for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now beyond the business district, Woody passes a tiny hou where an old man sits out front watching the traffic -- w it’s Uncle Albert. He lights up and waves.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: So long, Albert.  Blue (10-12-2012) 91.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE ALBERT
dialogues.text: So long, Woody. David pops back up as the truck continues down the street toward the setting sun. But before they continue on home, Woody stops the truck, and he and David exchange places.
